content.user_title: Design RESTful APIs with Best Practices
content.value_statement: Building APIs requires careful attention to routing, versioning, and HTTP standards to ensure maintainability and usability. This skill provides expert guidance on creating clean, well-structured APIs that follow industry best practices.
actual_capabilities: Design RESTful API endpoints with proper HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE)
Implement API versioning strategies (URL path or header-based)
Configure query parameters for filtering, sorting, and pagination
Apply correct HTTP status codes for API responses
Set up rate limiting and API throttling configurations
Create API resource transformation classes for response formatting
limitations: Provides guidance only; does not generate or modify code directly
Focuses on RESTful patterns; may not cover GraphQL or gRPC APIs
Assumes existing Laravel or similar backend framework knowledge

prompt_templates.title: Create Resource Endpoint
prompt_templates.scenario: Building a new API endpoint for a resource
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a RESTful API endpoint for managing [resource_name]. Include proper routing, controller methods for CRUD operations, and appropriate HTTP status codes.

prompt_templates.title: Add Pagination
prompt_templates.prompt: Add pagination support to the existing [endpoint_name] API endpoint. Include query parameters for page number and limit, with proper response metadata.

prompt_templates.title: Version API
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement API versioning for [api_name]. Should I use URL path versioning (/api/v1/) or header-based versioning? Provide configuration and migration steps.

prompt_templates.title: Add Rate Limiting
prompt_templates.prompt: Add rate limiting to the [endpoint_name] API endpoint. Configure appropriate limits per user and include rate limit headers in responses.

output_examples.input: Create a users API with pagination and filtering
output: GET /api/v1/users - List all users with optional filters (page, limit, sort, search)
GET /api/v1/users/{id} - Retrieve single user by ID
POST /api/v1/users - Create new user with validation
Response includes: data array, meta object with pagination info, links for navigation
Rate limit: 60 requests per minute with X-RateLimit headers

best_practices: Use consistent URL naming conventions (plural nouns for resources, kebab-case)
Always return appropriate HTTP status codes (200, 201, 400, 404, 422, 500)
Include pagination metadata and rate limit headers in all list endpoints
anti_patterns: Using verbs in URLs instead of nouns (e.g., /getUsers instead of /users)
Returning different response structures for success and error cases
Exposing internal database IDs in API responses; use UUIDs instead

faq.question: Which API versioning approach should I use?
faq.answer: URL path versioning (/api/v1/) is simpler and more discoverable. Header-based versioning is cleaner but requires more client setup.

faq.question: What HTTP status codes should I use?
faq.answer: Use 200 for success, 201 for created resources, 400 for bad requests, 401 for auth failures, 404 for not found, 422 for validation errors, and 500 for server errors.

faq.question: How do I handle pagination efficiently?
faq.answer: Use cursor-based pagination for large datasets or offset-based with limit parameters. Always include total count and next/previous links.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a prompt-based skill that only provides guidance. It does not access, store, or transmit any data.

faq.question: Why is my API slow with pagination?
faq.answer: Ensure proper database indexes on filtered columns. Use cursor pagination for large datasets to avoid OFFSET calculation overhead.

faq.question: How does this compare to API management platforms?
faq.answer: This skill provides coding guidance for building APIs. It does not replace API gateways or management platforms that handle authentication, caching, and monitoring.
